 MLB headnote and full text 
 
 
 
 In the Matter Of the Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29; 
 
 
 
 And In The Matter Of an appeal from the decision of a Citizenship Judge; 
 
 
 
 And In The Matter Of Talat Yousefi (appellant). 
 
 (T-2393-93) 
 
 
 
 Indexed As: Yousefi, Re 
 
 
 
 Federal Court of Canada 
 
 Trial Division 
 
 Denault, J. 
 
 February 24, 1995. 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 
 A citizenship judge dismissed Yousefi's application for Canadian citizenship on the ground that she did not meet the requirements of ss. 5(1)(d) and 5(1)(e) of the Citizenship Act. The judge also discarded a medical report which stated that Yousefi's medical condition prevented her from meeting those requirements and decided that there was no basis for recommending that the requirements be waived under ss. 5(3)(a) or 5(4) of the Act. Yousefi appealed. 
 
 
 
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, held that unless the citizenship judge had good reasons to set the medical report aside, she should have at least recommended that the requirements of ss. 5(1)(d) and 5(1)(e) be waived under ss. 5(3)(a) and 5(4). The court made such a recommendation.

 Counsel: 
 
 Talat Yousefi, on her own behalf; 
 
 Andrew Epstein, as amicus curiae. 
 
 
 
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 Singleton, Urquhart, Vancouver, British Columbia, as amicus curiae. 
 
 
 
 This appeal was heard on February 21, 1995, at Vancouver, British Columbia, before Denault, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, who delivered the following judgment on February 24, 1995.

[1] 
   
 Denault, J. 
 : The appellant is appealing from a decision by a citizenship judge on August 10, 1993, dismissing her application for Canadian citizenship on the ground that she does not meet the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 . After examining the applicant, the judge also found that there was no basis for her recommending that the Minister exercise discretionary powers on compassionate grounds pursuant to s. 5(3)(a) of the  
 Act 
 .

[2] 
  The appellant, who was assisted by an interpreter since she does not have an adequate knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada, testified in court. Her husband, accompanying her, also intervened in favour of his wife, manifestly a sick woman.

[3] 
  The evidence disclosed that the appellant, born in 1929 in Iran, was granted permanent resident status in Canada in May 1990. Since her arrival, she has lived in the Vancouver area with her husband.

[4] 
  As was indicated by the presence of an Iranian interpreter, the appellant does not have an adequate knowledge of one of the official languages of Canada. She could hardly answer very simple questions. She testified having tried to learn English through tapes and T.V. shows but could not identify - she did not even seem to understand the question - these shows.

[5] 
  The summary examination to determine her knowledge of her new country indicates that it is still very limited. She identified the Prime Minister of Canada as being Raymond (Romeo?) Leblanc, and then Elizabeth (II?), and finally Jean Chrétien.

[6] 
  In short, she does not meet the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 .

[7] 
  However, I understood from her husband's intervention that the Minister should in his discretion waive these conditions on compassionate grounds (ss. 5(3)(a) and 5(4)). Before the appellant appeared before the citizenship judge, a request for medical opinion was required, and filed by her family physician, Dr. Shamim Jetha. He states in his medical report that the applicant's medical condition prevents her from meeting the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the  
 Act 
  on the grounds that she has been suffering from "chronic pain (generalized) for several years and she has seen many specialists and is still being investigated". The citizenship judge, without any contradicting evidence, discarded that evidence and "decided against making an affirmative recommendation under ss. 5(3) or 5(4) of the  
 Act 
 , since there was no evidence of any health disability, or of any special or unusual hardship ...". In my opinion, this was an error. Unless the citizenship judge had good and valid reasons to set that medical report aside, she had, on the basis of it, to at least make a recommendation that the Minister should waive the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the  
 Citizenship Act 
  with respect to the appellant on compassionate grounds, pursuant to s. 5(3)(a) and because it would impose unusual hardship upon the appellant, pursuant to s. 5(4) of the  
 Act 
 . This is my recommendation. 
 
 
 
 Order accordingly. 
 
 
 
 Editor: Angela E. McKay/sg 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

Citizenship Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29, sect. 5(4)
legal_issues: The extent to which a citizenship judge must consider and respond to medical evidence presented in support of a citizenship application.
The standard of justification required for a citizenship judge to disregard medical evidence regarding an applicant's ability to meet citizenship requirements.
The circumstances under which a citizenship judge should recommend a waiver of statutory requirements based on compassionate grounds or unusual hardship.
The proper application of discretionary powers allowing for the waiver of citizenship requirements.
The evidentiary burden and assessment of an applicant's knowledge of official languages as a prerequisite for citizenship.
factual_background: An individual born in Iran in 1929 applied for Canadian citizenship.
The applicant was granted permanent resident status in Canada in May 1990 and resided in the Vancouver area.
The applicant has limited knowledge of English and one of Canada’s official languages, relying on an interpreter.
The applicant demonstrated limited knowledge of Canadian civics, misidentifying the Prime Minister.
A medical report from the applicant’s physician stated a chronic pain condition prevented the applicant from meeting language and civics requirements for citizenship.
A citizenship judge dismissed the application, finding the applicant did not meet requirements outlined in sections 5(1)(d) and 5(1)(e) of the Citizenship Act.
The citizenship judge did not recommend a waiver of the requirements based on compassionate grounds (section 5(3)(a)) or unusual hardship (section 5(4)), despite the medical report.
The applicant appealed the citizenship judge’s decision.

Applicants: The requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act should be waived on compassionate grounds (ss. 5(3)(a) and 5(4)).
The appellant’s medical condition prevents her from meeting the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act, as supported by a medical report from Dr. Shamim Jetha.
The appellant has attempted to learn an official language through tapes and television, despite limited success.
The appellant has been a permanent resident since May 1990 and resides in Canada with her husband.
Respondents: The appellant does not meet the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act due to inadequate knowledge of an official language and limited knowledge of Canada.
There was no evidence of any health disability or special/unusual hardship justifying a recommendation for waiver under ss. 5(3) or 5(4) of the Act.

court_analysis: The court found that the citizenship judge erred in dismissing the appellant’s application without properly considering a medical report submitted by her physician.
The medical report stated the appellant’s chronic pain prevented her from meeting the language and knowledge requirements of sections 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act.
The court emphasized that the judge discarded the medical report without presenting any contradictory evidence, which constituted an error in judgment.

The court reasoned that, absent valid reasons to disregard the medical report, the judge was obligated to recommend a waiver of the requirements under sections 5(3)(a) (compassionate grounds) and 5(4) (unusual hardship) of the Citizenship Act.

The court interpreted the Citizenship Act to require a recommendation for waiver when medical evidence supports a claim of inability to meet the standard requirements, unless there is evidence to undermine that medical opinion.

The court explicitly made a recommendation that the Minister waive the requirements of sections 5(1)(d) and (e) based on the unchallenged medical report, citing both compassionate grounds and the potential for unusual hardship.
final_outcome: Recommendation made to the Minister to waive the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act on compassionate grounds pursuant to s. 5(3)(a).
Recommendation made to the Minister to waive the requirements of s. 5(1)(d) and (e) of the Citizenship Act because it would impose unusual hardship upon the appellant, pursuant to s. 5(4).
